Gi·ªõi thi·ªáu: V·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ Overfitting trong Machine Learning

T·∫°i sao c·∫ßn Regularization?

H√£y xem x√©t b√†i to√°n h·ªìi quy tuy·∫øn t√≠nh c∆° b·∫£n: \(\min_{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{2n} \|\mathbf{X}\mathbf{w} - \mathbf{y}\|_2^2\)

Gi·∫£i ph√°p: Th√™m regularization term ƒë·ªÉ ‚Äúph·∫°t‚Äù c√°c tr·ªçng s·ªë l·ªõn: \(\min_{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{2n} \|\mathbf{X}\mathbf{w} - \mathbf{y}\|_2^2 + \lambda R(\mathbf{w})\)

  • \(\lambda > 0\) l√† regularization parameter
  • \(R(\mathbf{w})\) l√† regularization function

Ridge Regression (L2 Regularization)

ƒê·ªãnh nghƒ©a To√°n h·ªçc

Ridge regression s·ª≠ d·ª•ng L2 norm l√†m regularization term:

\[\min_{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{2n} \|\mathbf{X}\mathbf{w} - \mathbf{y}\|_2^2 + \frac{\lambda}{2} \|\mathbf{w}\|_2^2\]

Gi·∫£i th√≠ch c√°c th√†nh ph·∫ßn:

  • Loss term: \(\frac{1}{2n} \|\mathbf{X}\mathbf{w} - \mathbf{y}\|_2^2\) - ƒëo l∆∞·ªùng ƒë·ªô l·ªách gi·ªØa d·ª± ƒëo√°n v√† th·ª±c t·∫ø
  • Regularization term: \(\frac{\lambda}{2} \|\mathbf{w}\|_2^2 = \frac{\lambda}{2} \sum_{j=1}^p w_j^2\) - ph·∫°t c√°c tr·ªçng s·ªë l·ªõn
  • Regularization strength: \(\lambda\) ki·ªÉm so√°t m·ª©c ƒë·ªô regularization

Nghi·ªám Gi·∫£i t√≠ch

Ridge regression c√≥ nghi·ªám d·∫°ng ƒë√≥ng: \(\mathbf{w}^* = (\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} + \lambda \mathbf{I})^{-1} \mathbf{X}^T \mathbf{y}\)

∆Øu ƒëi·ªÉm c·ªßa nghi·ªám n√†y:

  • Ma tr·∫≠n \((\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} + \lambda \mathbf{I})\) lu√¥n kh·∫£ ngh·ªãch khi \(\lambda > 0\)
  • Gi·∫£i quy·∫øt v·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ multicollinearity
  • T√≠nh to√°n hi·ªáu qu·∫£

Practical Example: Minimizing a Quadratic Function

ƒê·ªÉ hi·ªÉu s√¢u h∆°n v·ªÅ regularization, h√£y xem x√©t m·ªôt v√≠ d·ª• c·ª• th·ªÉ v·ªõi quadratic function. ƒê√¢y l√† n·ªÅn t·∫£ng to√°n h·ªçc cho nhi·ªÅu thu·∫≠t to√°n machine learning.

B√†i to√°n: Portfolio Optimization v·ªõi Regularization

Gi·∫£ s·ª≠ ch√∫ng ta c√≥ b√†i to√°n t·ªëi ∆∞u h√≥a danh m·ª•c ƒë·∫ßu t∆∞:

\[\min_{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{2} \mathbf{w}^T \mathbf{Q} \mathbf{w} - \mathbf{\mu}^T \mathbf{w} + \frac{\lambda}{2} \|\mathbf{w}\|_2^2\]

trong ƒë√≥:

  • \(\mathbf{w} \in \mathbb{R}^n\): tr·ªçng s·ªë ƒë·∫ßu t∆∞ cho \(n\) t√†i s·∫£n
  • \(\mathbf{Q} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}\): ma tr·∫≠n hi·ªáp ph∆∞∆°ng sai (risk matrix)
  • \(\mathbf{\mu} \in \mathbb{R}^n\): vector l·ª£i nhu·∫≠n k·ª≥ v·ªçng
  • \(\lambda > 0\): tham s·ªë regularization (risk aversion)

Ph√¢n t√≠ch To√°n h·ªçc Chi ti·∫øt

1. Gradient c·ªßa Objective Function

\[\nabla f(\mathbf{w}) = \mathbf{Q}\mathbf{w} - \mathbf{\mu} + \lambda \mathbf{w} = (\mathbf{Q} + \lambda \mathbf{I})\mathbf{w} - \mathbf{\mu}\]

2. Hessian Matrix

\[\nabla^2 f(\mathbf{w}) = \mathbf{Q} + \lambda \mathbf{I}\]

Quan s√°t quan tr·ªçng:

  • Khi \(\lambda > 0\), Hessian lu√¥n positive definite (n·∫øu \(\mathbf{Q}\) positive semidefinite)
  • ƒêi·ªÅu n√†y ƒë·∫£m b·∫£o h√†m m·ª•c ti√™u l√† strongly convex
  • Nghi·ªám t·ªëi ∆∞u duy nh·∫•t t·ªìn t·∫°i

3. Nghi·ªám T·ªëi ∆∞u

ƒê·∫∑t gradient b·∫±ng 0: \((\mathbf{Q} + \lambda \mathbf{I})\mathbf{w}^* = \mathbf{\mu}\)

\[\mathbf{w}^* = (\mathbf{Q} + \lambda \mathbf{I})^{-1} \mathbf{\mu}\]

Gradient Descent cho Quadratic Functions

ƒê·ªëi v·ªõi quadratic function, gradient descent c√≥ d·∫°ng ƒë·∫∑c bi·ªát:

\[\mathbf{w}^{(k+1)} = \mathbf{w}^{(k)} - \alpha [(\mathbf{Q} + \lambda \mathbf{I})\mathbf{w}^{(k)} - \mathbf{\mu}]\]

Ph√¢n t√≠ch Convergence Rate

Eigenvalue decomposition: \(\mathbf{Q} + \lambda \mathbf{I} = \mathbf{V} \mathbf{\Lambda} \mathbf{V}^T\)

Convergence rate: $$\rho = \max_i \left 1 - \alpha \lambda_i\right $$

trong ƒë√≥ \(\lambda_i\) l√† eigenvalues c·ªßa \(\mathbf{Q} + \lambda \mathbf{I}\).

Optimal step size: \(\alpha^* = \frac{2}{\lambda_{\min} + \lambda_{\max}}\)

Convergence factor: \(\rho^* = \frac{\kappa - 1}{\kappa + 1}\)

trong ƒë√≥ \(\kappa = \frac{\lambda_{\max}}{\lambda_{\min}}\) l√† condition number.

Case Study: Ill-conditioned Problems

V·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ: Multicollinearity trong Linear Regression

Xem x√©t ma tr·∫≠n thi·∫øt k·∫ø \(\mathbf{X}\) v·ªõi c√°c c·ªôt g·∫ßn nh∆∞ ph·ª• thu·ªôc tuy·∫øn t√≠nh:

\[\mathbf{X} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1.001 \\ 1 & 2 & 2.001 \\ 1 & 3 & 3.001 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \end{bmatrix}\]

Normal equations: \(\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} \mathbf{w} = \mathbf{X}^T \mathbf{y}\)

V·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ: \(\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X}\) c√≥ condition number r·∫•t l·ªõn ‚Üí numerical instability

Gi·∫£i ph√°p: Ridge Regularization

\[(\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} + \lambda \mathbf{I}) \mathbf{w} = \mathbf{X}^T \mathbf{y}\]

Hi·ªáu qu·∫£:

  • Condition number gi·∫£m t·ª´ \(10^{12}\) xu·ªëng \(10^2\)
  • Numerical stability ƒë∆∞·ª£c c·∫£i thi·ªán ƒë√°ng k·ªÉ
  • Trade-off: bias tƒÉng nh∆∞ng variance gi·∫£m

Mathematical Insights

1. Bias-Variance Decomposition

ƒê·ªëi v·ªõi Ridge regression:

\[\text{MSE} = \text{Bias}^2 + \text{Variance} + \text{Noise}\]

Bias: \(\mathbb{E}[\hat{\mathbf{w}}] - \mathbf{w}^* = -\lambda (\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} + \lambda \mathbf{I})^{-1} \mathbf{w}^*\)

Variance: \(\text{Var}[\hat{\mathbf{w}}] = \sigma^2 (\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} + \lambda \mathbf{I})^{-1} \mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} (\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} + \lambda \mathbf{I})^{-1}\)

2. Effective Degrees of Freedom

\[\text{df}(\lambda) = \text{tr}[\mathbf{X}(\mathbf{X}^T\mathbf{X} + \lambda \mathbf{I})^{-1}\mathbf{X}^T] = \sum_{i=1}^p \frac{\sigma_i^2}{\sigma_i^2 + \lambda}\]

trong ƒë√≥ \(\sigma_i^2\) l√† singular values c·ªßa \(\mathbf{X}\).

Interpretation: Regularization effectively reduces model complexity.

Computational Considerations

1. Direct Solution vs Iterative Methods

Direct (Cholesky decomposition):

  • Complexity: \(O(p^3)\)
  • Suitable for \(p < 10^4\)
  • Numerically stable with regularization

Iterative (Gradient descent):

  • Complexity per iteration: \(O(np)\)
  • Suitable for large \(p\)
  • Convergence depends on condition number

2. Preconditioning

Jacobi preconditioning: \(\mathbf{P} = \text{diag}(\mathbf{Q} + \lambda \mathbf{I})\)

Preconditioned system: \(\mathbf{P}^{-1}(\mathbf{Q} + \lambda \mathbf{I})\mathbf{w} = \mathbf{P}^{-1}\mathbf{\mu}\)

Benefit: Improved condition number ‚Üí faster convergence

Lasso Regression (L1 Regularization)

ƒê·ªãnh nghƒ©a To√°n h·ªçc

Lasso (Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator) s·ª≠ d·ª•ng L1 norm:

\[\min_{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{2n} \|\mathbf{X}\mathbf{w} - \mathbf{y}\|_2^2 + \lambda \|\mathbf{w}\|_1\]
trong ƒë√≥ $$|\mathbf{w}|1 = \sum{j=1}^p w_j $$

ƒê·∫∑c ƒëi·ªÉm Quan tr·ªçng c·ªßa Lasso

1. Sparse Solutions (Nghi·ªám th∆∞a):

  • Lasso c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë·∫∑t m·ªôt s·ªë coefficients v·ªÅ ch√≠nh x√°c b·∫±ng 0
  • T·ª± ƒë·ªông th·ª±c hi·ªán feature selection
  • T·∫°o ra m√¥ h√¨nh ƒë∆°n gi·∫£n, d·ªÖ di·ªÖn gi·∫£i

2. Kh√¥ng c√≥ nghi·ªám d·∫°ng ƒë√≥ng:

  • C·∫ßn s·ª≠ d·ª•ng thu·∫≠t to√°n t·ªëi ∆∞u h√≥a (coordinate descent, proximal gradient)
  • Ph·ª©c t·∫°p t√≠nh to√°n h∆°n Ridge

H√¨nh h·ªçc c·ªßa Regularization

  3. Intersection v·ªõi loss contours:

    • L2: Th∆∞·ªùng giao t·∫°i c√°c ƒëi·ªÉm smooth (non-sparse solutions)

Elastic Net: K·∫øt h·ª£p Ridge v√† Lasso

Elastic Net k·∫øt h·ª£p c·∫£ L1 v√† L2 regularization:

\[\min_{\mathbf{w}} \frac{1}{2n} \|\mathbf{X}\mathbf{w} - \mathbf{y}\|_2^2 + \lambda \left[ \alpha \|\mathbf{w}\|_1 + \frac{1-\alpha}{2} \|\mathbf{w}\|_2^2 \right]\]

Tham s·ªë:

  • \(\alpha \in [0,1]\): mixing parameter
  • \(\alpha = 1\): Pure Lasso
  • \(\alpha = 0\): Pure Ridge
  • \(0 < \alpha < 1\): Combination

∆Øu ƒëi·ªÉm:

  • K·∫øt h·ª£p sparsity c·ªßa Lasso v·ªõi stability c·ªßa Ridge
  • X·ª≠ l√Ω t·ªët grouped variables
  • Ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông t·ªët khi \(p > n\)

Loss Functions trong Machine Learning

1. Regression Loss Functions

Mean Squared Error (MSE)

\(L_{MSE}(\mathbf{w}) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \mathbf{w}^T \mathbf{x}_i)^2\)

ƒê·∫∑c ƒëi·ªÉm:

  • Smooth, differentiable everywhere
  • Sensitive to outliers
  • Convex optimization problem

Mean Absolute Error (MAE)

\(L_{MAE}(\mathbf{w}) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n |y_i - \mathbf{w}^T \mathbf{x}_i|\)

ƒê·∫∑c ƒëi·ªÉm:

  • Robust to outliers
  • Non-differentiable at zero
  • Convex but requires subgradient methods

Huber Loss

\(L_{Huber}(\mathbf{w}) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n \begin{cases} \frac{1}{2}(y_i - \mathbf{w}^T \mathbf{x}_i)^2 & \text{if } |y_i - \mathbf{w}^T \mathbf{x}_i| \leq \delta \\ \delta |y_i - \mathbf{w}^T \mathbf{x}_i| - \frac{1}{2}\delta^2 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\)

ƒê·∫∑c ƒëi·ªÉm:

  • Combines MSE (small errors) and MAE (large errors)
  • Smooth and robust
  • Parameter \(\delta\) controls transition point

2. Classification Loss Functions

Logistic Loss (Cross-entropy)

\(L_{logistic}(\mathbf{w}) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n \log(1 + \exp(-y_i \mathbf{w}^T \mathbf{x}_i))\)

Hinge Loss (SVM)

\(L_{hinge}(\mathbf{w}) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n \max(0, 1 - y_i \mathbf{w}^T \mathbf{x}_i)\)

Practical Guidelines v√† Best Practices

S·ª≠ d·ª•ng Lasso khi:

  • Mu·ªën m√¥ h√¨nh ƒë∆°n gi·∫£n, d·ªÖ di·ªÖn gi·∫£i
  • Sparse solutions ƒë∆∞·ª£c ∆∞a chu·ªông

2. Hyperparameter Tuning Strategy

# Pseudo-code cho regularization tuning
def tune_regularization(X_train, y_train, X_val, y_val):
    lambda_values = np.logspace(-4, 2, 50)  # Log-spaced values
    best_lambda = None
    best_score = float('inf')
    
    for lambda_val in lambda_values:
        model = fit_regularized_model(X_train, y_train, lambda_val)
        val_score = evaluate_model(model, X_val, y_val)
        
        if val_score < best_score:
            best_score = val_score
            best_lambda = lambda_val
    
    return best_lambda, best_score

3. Feature Scaling

Quan tr·ªçng: Regularization nh·∫°y c·∫£m v·ªõi scale c·ªßa features!

  • Ridge/Lasso: Y√™u c·∫ßu feature scaling (standardization)
  • L√Ω do: Regularization penalty ph·ª• thu·ªôc v√†o magnitude c·ªßa coefficients
  • Gi·∫£i ph√°p: Standardize features tr∆∞·ªõc khi √°p d·ª•ng regularization

K·∫øt lu·∫≠n v√† Takeaways

Practical Workflow:
